values:
I miss Hakim.

I've been thinking of posting that for 8 months mow, but I never use this thing. It doesn't matter. It doesn't change anything.

I owed you far more than I ever gave, and wish I had given it to you before. And not a moment has gone by I haven't thought that. 

And only coming back to livejournal after ages makes me think to write about again. But I've never forgotten.

I miss you.

It's fucking appropriate that in a drunken stupor I type into google alcoholic and come up with a Japanese import site.

http://www.alco-holic.com/

Also, I need to get my shit together.

And if you want to read my new blog: http://japanisanisland.wordpress.com/

Let's hope my next 8 weeks work out better than the last 8 did.

After coming home yesterday, I decided before messing around with the DVD burner I would rip a few more DVDs to the hard drive. Well, now the drive doesn't work at all. It recognizes DVDs and CDs, tries to play them, and then freezes. Games running off a CD? Freezes. I'm going to try messing with the IDE settings but I doubt it will fix it. Saturday is my day to mess around with this stuff, but I'm pretty convinced that trying to focus the layer for the second layer broke the lens. It's lucky i have two back up internal DVD-ROM drives laying around.

Fuck you I/O Magic. I'm pretty certain you sold me a defective product. I either want a new, free replacement drive from you or I'm buying one from a different company. Dual layer DVD burners from Sony are on sale for $25.

My entire evening last night was ruined. Wasted. All because of one issue I couldn't solve or let go. And like so many things in our modern life, it had to do with my computer.

I received a dual layer DVD burner for Christmas so I could back up my DVD collection. Yesterday I received the spindle of 50 dual layer discs I ordered online. I had to order them online, because you can't find them in almost any store anymore. I know because I looked everywhere. So I started backing up my DVDs, or at least trying to. Every time I tried to back one up there would be a write error, and the drive would freeze. I could close the writing software by terminating the process, but the drive would be in a continual lock trying to write something. The only way to stop it is to power down the machine.

I tried everything I could think of. I updated the firm ware for the drive. Tried a different burning software. rebooted, ran disk cleaner, turned off all other programs, bitmapped the disc. Nothing. It reads DVDs fine, and burns CDs and single layer DVDs with no problem. What good is a dual layer DVD burner that doesn't burn dual layer DVDs? Oh, and tech support is only open from 8am to 5pm Monday through Friday.

So I talked to tech support this morning. Suggestions are to change the jumper setting, dedicate the IDE cable to the drive, or try one of the reccomended brands of dual layer DVDRs. I ordered a new set that should be here Monday.

Grah.

I feel kind of melancholy today. I'm not sure if melancholy is the right word. I feel as if something is missing. 

From time to time I get these flashes -mental images of a place in my minds eye. Usually about Japan. I can see it so clearly today. Yamagata station. The stone tiles leading down the wide hall to the turnstiles. The station agents standing attentively at the side. In my mind I feel almost like I'm there again.

Something is tugging at my heart through my spine. I feel like I left something behind in Japan. Even if I returned I doubt I could get it back.

Is that strange?

This is my blog.
Sometimes I write things in it.
But I have not lately. I should do that more.

These are words.
They represent objects or actions, that when combined form ideas.
These ideas are generally inane.
As they are my ideas.

Hello Blog.

I've been using Facebook lately  to catch up with old friends, classmates, and keep up with people in general (I know, I'm behind the times.) There are a lot of people from my high school I spent time with at the tail end of my college career but lost touch with when I traded coasts. Realistically, I was allowing myself to lose contact with them because I needed to sort some things out for myself.

I went to contact one of these people, my friend Hakim, and found a lot of ominous goodbye messages on his wall. Turns out he passed away.

This is the second friend from high school I've had pass away this year. The second one I lost contact with and meant to catch up with. I'm at a loss for words. I don't know what to say or do.

And I'm left with an unanswerable why.

Those of you from my NU days will understand this better than anyone else. 

I feel like I'm not ever really satisfied where I am, and I'm not sure why. Maybe I'm just in a rambling state and not ready to settle down. I'm not sure that's it either. Job wise I'm really happy where I am (sadly it's a temp job and probably won't turn permanent.) When I was in Japan though I found myself longing for San Francisco. Now that I'm back I find myself longing for Japan and Boston. It's sort of like with NU. When you're in classes you want to be in Co-Op, when you're on Co-Op you'd rather have classes. I'm not unhappy here by any means. I just feel... unfulfilled.

I wonder what it is I'm missing.

After two years I finally watched Linda Linda Linda! I expected it to have more energy to it, like Swing Kids. Much more minimalist, like many of the better Japanese dramas are. They tend to go on either end of the spectrum: very minimalist or wacky overactive. It was a good film, and something I think I'll enjoy more on a second viewing. There was a scene towards the end of the film where the girls are walking home either late evening or early evening. The sky and the trees and the quiet... it was just... I forgot how absolutely gorgeous Japan is. Even this beautiful film scene doesn't do it justice. The sun seems so much brighter and younger. Everything seems more vibrant, alive and fresh. Saturated with genki. It's something I really miss about Japan. Especially with the gray overcast days we've had in San Francisco lately.

Brief little what the fuck do I do update.

I've been dating a Japanese woman studying English at Kaplan in Berkeley. Our relationship is a bit complicated, but we care a lot for each other. Last night I learned she becomes homeless this Saturday. 

I've been helping her to find an apartment, but we've yet to have any luck. I'm trying to push her to do some more house hunting on her own. In trying to get her to promise me she will she became unresponsive. I became frustrated, which in turn upset her, so much so that she's not talking to me. Literally. She was almost catatonic outside of the occasional crying most of last night and this morning. I think she may have broken up with me. I'm not sure. 

I'm terribly worried for her. I don't know what she's going to do, and she doesn't seem to want my help now. If she were talking to me, she could stay at my place until she found somewhere.

I also would like an uncomplicated relationship at some point my life.

I've been thinking about Japan a lot lately. I suppose that's not terribly unusual. I'm wondering what it would be like if I stayed another year. Should I have stayed another year?

While the experience overall was good, there are certain things that soured a bit of it for me. I think I entered it all with the wrong mindset. I was already determined to come back to California, so perhaps I wasn't wholly receptive to the people and things around me. The committed relationship I was in at the time feels as if it contributed to that. Though the term committed for that relationship doesn't feel right, more like obligated.

I wonder if I often approach things from the wrong angle. While I'm not sure how to elaborate either qualitatively or quantitatively, I worry I may too often make decisions based on what I think is best for others, or what I think will make people like me. I make these decisions rather than doing what is best for myself. Everyone needs to be a little selfish in life. I just worry I choose the wrong times. Do I take advantage of the people who actually care and support me while trying to please people who treat me with disregard?

I need to straighten out my priorities
Why has there not been a romhack to be like this?

So normally when moving out I've stuck by a rule that I always have more than I expect and it will take longer than I plan. I certainly have more than expect (partly because people keep giving me going away presents, not to sound ungrateful) and my luggage is stuffed.  But it took a lot less time than I expected.

I set aside a little time Thursday and Friday night last week, last weekend, yesterday and tomorrow to finish packing, cleaning the bedroom, kitchen, bathroom and toilet room (they're separate in Japan,) cancel and return my cellphone, internet and modem. I finished the bathroom and shower this weekend. Canceled and returned the cellphone yesterday. Canceled my internet last week (but have it active until Thursday.)  I expected to spend all day today and tomorrow packing and cleaning. 

I finished today at noon.

Spent most of the day sitting around, trying to pass the time. Read the news. Watched TV online. Played some games. But I can't shake it. I'm bored.

So, I've decided to go to Tokyo a day early. I checked and the hostel I'm staying at has open beds for tomorrow night. So I figure I'll leave around noon tomorrow. Don't know what I'll do before Post arrives Thursday but hell, its Toyko. I'm sure I'll find something to do,

I just received an e-mail that a friend of mine from high school passed away. We ran in the same circle of friend so we used to hang out a lot on weekends and we had a few classes together. I don't know that you could say we were close, but he was always someone pretty chill to hang out with. We hung out occasionally during freshman year of college but kind of drifted apart after that. I would always hear little tidbits of what was going on in his life from mutual friends here and there. I guess this is the last one I'll hear.

I don't know what the cause of death was yet. There's the possibility it was drugs which would be both surprising and not at the same time. While he did quite a bit of drugs he was always very smart about it. Scientific even, as he researched every drug, their effects composition and possible effects. He was a very smart guy, though not always very social. Funny how that sometimes goes hand in hand. It wasn't that his intellect alienated him from people and he never lorded it over anyone or acted superior. He was a good guy. 

I don't know what more to say.

So it's proven impossible to keep up with my live journal as much as I would like. Especially given how my computer is on its last legs.

I would like to write a lot more in greater detail than I am able, but time and consequence does not seem to allow it. It is not that i do not have much time these days (quite the opposite,) it just appears I am unable to make all of the updates I desire without something going wrong. I am going to try for a short weekly update, and hope that works out.

My arrival to Japan was uneventful for the most part, though it took me about an hour to figure out what I was doing and how to get to where I needed to go. On my second day in Japan, I finalized the paperwork, signed my contract and was taken to Yamagata.

Much of my early days in Japan were learning and adjusting. I am greatful for the little Japanese  I know and studied, and for the advice many of my Japan experienced friends have given. Stress builds up daily, but not in a manner of
anger or depression, simply a feeling of being overwhelmed. I've taken to long naps or being slightly vegatative for an hour after arriving home. I think this is how the stress manifests and is dealt with. It's interesting to be in a country where you there is so much new and to learn, with very little you can read or understand. As my fellow ALT friend Nick put it "It's like we're little children again, just without Mom and Dad to guide us."

The company gives little to nothing of a support network for its ALTs. Basically, we are left to fend for ourselves and learn on our own. This has its advantages and disadvantages and is completely opposite of the JET program. In comparison they are pampered and groomed. Any ease in my transition is thanks to an American native English teacher who had lived in the building adjacent to me. When she saw me, she sought me out and helped make sure I knew the basics of the city and what to be aware of. She left with her boyfriend to travel the world, so sadly she is gone. Still, and thankful for Heather's help.

Possibly the biggest obstacle I have faced since arriving here is the bureaucracy and the unknown issue that has withheld my work visa. Without it, I cannot recieve my gaijin (foriegner) card. Without my Gaijin card, I cannot get internet, a cellphone or a bank account. It has made a difficult situation even more frustrating. 

Where I am living is the second smallest city in Japan. We are surroundd by farmland and mountains, so where I am living could be acquaited with the American Midwest. Just north of our mountains is the setting for Princess Mononoke, and we are one of the only cities left untouched by World War 2. Things here are quiet,  slower and more relaxed.  At the same time, they can be very lonely and boring. I find myself thinking a lot, at first when I arrived questioning what I was doing here but now wondering what I am going to do with the rest of my life.

I should spend more time writing, part to improve my ability and part to prepare scripts and screenplays to recraft and produce when I return. Meanwhile, I have decided to undertake a documntary project, something of a travel film, documenting living in nowhere city Japan for myself and two other ALTs I am friends with. We make an interesting mix of personalities with different backgrounds and situations coming into Japan. While I'm still working thee finer details of the project, I see much room for potential.

Finally, I learned Saturday that Candice will not be able to come and visit me in December - January as we had originally planned. This leaves me feeling a bit more lonely and with a lot more thinking to do. It is probably fortunate that I have finally established a fairly tight group of five guy friends out here.

More to come as it keeps on.

Greetings from Mito,  Japan. The current temperature is 36 degrees Celsius, and while I'm not certain of the exact conversion to  Fahrenheit, I'm pretty sure it's somewhere between hot as balls and hell. It took me a while to figure  out how to use the  air conditioner (remote control, and all in Japanese) but now that I have I'm much happier. I'm posting from my hotel room, which may be the last internet access I have for a week or so. Don't be sad, I'll be online again soon  enough.

My flight was smooth and without incident, but it took me a while to figure things out when I arrived  at the airport. Mostly because I was lugging all my baggage around. If I were to do this over, I would have only brought one bag and have the rest  shipped, cost be damned.

This country is beautiful. I had a three hour drive to Mito station  from  the airport, and there is so much green everywhere. Chains of houses and stores, both traditional and modern, dot the streets and  mix with the scenery rather than impose. I felt  like  I  was halfway between the suburbs and the country side. Even the city of Mito feels- even, spaced, clean- feels alive  and  green despite  all  the  neon. It's rather breathe taking.

After disembarking at Mito station (and being reprimanded for bringing 3 bags instead of one by the driver) it was time to find a taxi. Where were the taxis...

An older woman and her daughter (college age probably) who saw me struggling with my luggage approached me.

Daughter:  Wakarimasu ka? (Do you understand?)
Me: Chyotto (a litte.)
Daughter:  Are you lost?
Me: Not entirely, I need to find a  taxi to get to my  hotel.
  Mother speaks to daughter in Japanese, explains situation
Daughter: Taxis... the taxis should be over there. Are you sure you're okay?
Me:  I should be okay now. Thank you so much.

A delightfully nice woman, and  very accommodating. I made my way to a taxi, told  him my destination, and after one wrong turn we arrived  at my hotel. I checked in, washed off in the sink (wishing there was a shower on site) and took an hour to recoup. 

I'll try and post more later,  but I'm  running low  on time and  need to go meet Eri.

The more I learn about where I'll be staying the more nervous and worried I get. The area isn't dangerous or anything, it's just not what I expected. I partly signed up with this company because I was given the impression all of their placements were in the Kanto region, a short distance from Tokyo (relatively, anyway.) Where I will be is like being in DC relative to New York. 

A few of my friends with eztensive Japanese experience have told me several things that worry me, though. Yamagata has a very small 20s - 30s crowd and has it's own dialect that sounds backwards from regular Japanese(wikipedia confirms.) So the little Japanese I do know might be useless, and I may have trouble befriending people my own age, simply because there aren't many.

A friend put it to me this way though: I'm going to visit Tokyo much more often than I would if I stayed in San Francisco (even if it's only once or twice,) I'll be getting the "real" Japanese expereince, and things will be much less expensive than near Tokyo. I'll have a once in a lifetime experience, and get to do and see so many things.

I don't know why I worry. Will it be difficult? At first. But there's so much to do how can I pass that up. Plus I get the chance to enrich the minds and lives of children, and knowing what my teacher friends tell me, they'll probably enrich mind just as much.

I can't wait.

How often do I post in this thing? Never been good in keeping up with blogs and such. Always say I'll change that but...


Anyhow, I post when something important happens, like a big change. Well guess what we have.

That's right, a big change. I recently took a job with Heart English School in Mito, Ibraki, Japan as an Assistant Language Teacher. Similar to the JET program, but it's by a private company. I'm being placed in Yamagata City, in the Yamagata prefecture of the Tohoku region. That's in the mid North, 3 hours by bullet train to Tokyo. Means I won't get to go to Tokyo too often, but then again I'll be going more often than I would if I stayed here.

I don't know much about the details of the city or it's industry and surroundings, I still need to do more research. Being farther from Tokyo though I'm hoping costs or less and that will save me some money. 

I have a lot of packing and preparing to do, and a lot of people to say good bye to. I've put in my resignation, have my last day on the 8th and I'm shooting to arrive in Japan on the 14th. I'll be coming back to San Francisco afterwards, but if I can I may take a stop over in Boston first. I'll cross that bridge when I get to it.

I'll be posting more as the days pass. Expect a break in posting because it will take a few days to get internet set up in the new place.

I've mostly wrote about the negative lately, so I thought I'd write about some of the positive events in my life these days.

I've been working the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival, and the entire event has me on a high. It's great to be able to see all of these great movies with the directors there, and the running around getting to know new people is pretty cool too. At the end of the festival is a volunteer appreciation party, which should be pretty fun. I don't know of any other festival that does that.

Saturday I went to my friend Chris's co-worker's party (Kim) which was a pretty good time. Her two bi lady friends ended up getting it on in her room, and she was a little upset about that. Can't blame her really; I for one have a "No one has sex in or on my bed but me" rule. 

She was also upset because it's been a while for her, which is surprising given as she is drop dead gorgeous and has an amazing body. I almost wanted to say to her "Really? How hard have you been trying? If all you want is sex it's pretty easy to come by in this city." I'm pretty sure she's not the type to just bring guys home though, which gives her points in my book. 

She was kind of excited I was working the festival, too. Oh, and she gave me her number so that we might hang out some time.

Nothing else of great consequence. I haven't seen Safire since our last outing, but we've been calling back and forth. She's been a bit busy with classes and performances and some limited socializing. If she's not in Rhode Island this weekend for a gig I will probably see her. Even if not something about our last phone call made me really happy. I can't explain it.

I guess I'll end with a note that I've learned the joy of cooking with eggs. Sunny side up is delicious.

...with a friend who does not seem to trust you, and you have only limited respect for? This goes back to my last posting. I'm not so wound up about it anymore, but it is slightly frustrating.

The situation is essentially this: I've decided to put some distance between myself and Carla. She's free to live her life as she chooses and I are still friends.

Here is where the trouble comes into play. 

Last Friday we all went out for drinks. Carla gets hammered beyond recognition, as per usual. Towards the end of the night, we are making our way back towards her neighborhood. The original plan was for an afterparty at her place. I see her in the back of the crowd, lagging behind, stumbling drunk and barely able to put one foot front of the other. Needless to say, I'm concerned.

So I go over to talk to her and help her walk back. I ask her if she's okay, and we talk a little, the details of this conversation are a bit fuzzy as I was a bit drunk at that point too. The conversation some how leads to her not making out with anyone that night and bringing people back to her place. I say something akin to "You can bring who ever you want home and have whatever fun you want, I just want to make sure you get home safe." She starts saying she doesn't want to have sex tonight and doesn't want to sleep with me, and I tell her I don't want to sleep with you, I just want to make sure you get home safe.

She shoves me off, and goes to our new friends Kathryn and Gabriel we had made that night adn completely ignores me. She wants them to walk her home and not me. Trouble is they don't know where she lives. Neither does Carla at this point (I had to stop her from taking wrong turns three times.) So I have to guide them all back, otherwise I would have left her to her own devices.

It's upsetting I'm trying to be friends with someone who only thinks I want to sleep with them.

But it appears I am posting in my live journal again. This is one of those things I want to be more consistent with, but have not been terribly good about. I want to say it's because I'm busy but that's a half truth. I don't really have a sense of focus right now is more of the case. I kind of need to work on that.

There are probably a lot of things to update about but I'll keep this short and do it over a couple of days. Let's start with this weekend.

I went to volunteer orientation for the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival, which appears is about as old as I am (this is the 25 festival.) The line up looks very good and I'm looking forward to working the festival, though I feel a little out of place being one of 5 white volunteers. That feeling won't last though. There appear to be a large number of Asian American transplant from Boston at the festival, noted by the 5 Red Sox T-shirts I saw, and the one girl in front of me on the sign up sheet who had a 617 area code. She walked away before I could strike up a conversation, though. On an odd side note, this is the first festival I have worked that has a death and dismemberment clause.

I also had a small housewarming on Saturday evening, with about 12 of my friends just relaxing an chatting over a drink. It was a good time. My roommate and I cleaned the place fairly thoroughly and re-arranged the furniture and it as a very homey feel to it now. It makes me happy beacuse the level of disarray was starting to get ot me. I'll have to take some pictures and put them up soon.

That's about it for now, but more to come.

Well, there goes my plan to try and update this every other day. I'm going to try and be better abotu updating this more frequently though.


A lot has happened, and not surprisingly since a lot of time has passed. Mainly, I have a new job and a new apartment. 

I move into my new place tonight, a two bedroom in Russian Hill. I'd equate Russian Hill with New York's Upper East side. I don't know if that's entirely accurate, but I think of them simiarly. They're both beautiful, safe, socially accessible and expensive areas. I lucked out because I found a room for an affordable price. My roommate is super cool and we get along pretty well so far, both being big geeks probably helps. There's a rooftop patio, and since I live at one of the highest points in San Francisco, you can see everything from it. The downhill ride to work is kind of nice, though the uphill commute back is less so. In stereotypical San Francisco style though, a trolley car goes right by it, so I can always take that to and from work.

I started a temp to hire job just before Thanksgiving, which is going very well so I'm hoping it turns to full hire. The company is Informatix, Inc. They're an IT company based in the San Francisco Financial District that does government contracting work on Child Care services. They basically make sure needy kids get what they need from what I understand. I like being a part of that. I'm working an administrative job, so while it's not what I want to do for the rest of my life, it's not something I'm terribly displeased in doing either. The work is not terribly stressful (though it fluxes between super busy and super slow) and it is all things I feel confident in doing and doing well. The best part is my coworkers. They are all very frinedly and thoughtful.  While I'm probaly the youngest person at this company by 6 years, I'm comfortable and feel like I can relate to all of my coworkers. There's still no definite I will be a permanent, but it seems more likely than not. I know I'm hoping for it (and have a few other admin pulling for me.)

The thing I am most excited for right now is I am coming home from Christmas for three weeks. This is the only time I will be able to come home all year, so I'm looking forward to it. It will be good to be back in Boston and able to see all of my friends again. And I better see them, despite them being busy with the holidays. Otherwise I will be sad.

I know you all soon.

Posting to note that I did not forget to post, simply that so much is going on I haven't had the time. Isn't that always the way? Interesting week, events including my meeting and dating a Japanese flight attendant who lives in Tokyo, and awesome Hat themed party, a Sunday of good movies, good food, good drinks and good friends.

I'll post in detail later in the week.

Catching up from the rest of the weekend, which really wasn't all that interesting. 

Friday I recovered from Thursday night, and did some experimentation with my computer. I've loaded a bunch of software to solve previous video editing/source problems. I want to make a few shorts (a movie trailer, a short commercial, etc.) to keep my skills sharp and showcase my abilities. Hell, I can use it to build a demo reel and maybe get a job.

In the evening I went to go see Borat, since everone seems to think I am him. It was funny, and better than I expected but more of a flavor of the week than anything.

Saturday I bummed around the house, started twiddling with the trailer I'm trying to put together, and eventually got off my butt and went to Amoeba Records. Trouble with going to Amoeba is I always find things I want to buy. I picked up four DVDs: Mirrormask, To Never Lose, Clean, and Three Times. I watched To Never Lose, wrapped myself in my blanket and had a quiet night to myself.

Sunday was my busy day. I went to see an apartment in Lower Haight at 1pm occupied by two lovely ladies. I sadly did not get the spot in the room, but I'm going to keep looking in the area because the Haight would be an incredible place to live. They said they're going to call me for their next theme party, which if they actually did would be really cool.

I called Nadia after looking at the apartment to chat, and she invited me down to Zietgeist, a dive bar on the edge of lower haight and castro. Seems that she and a few others go there every Sunday, so it seems like I have a new Sunday ritual.

I unfortunately wasn't able to stay very long because I had to get to the Embarcadero plaza to volunteer at the New Italian Cinema Event. Since it was opening event I was able to attend the reception, which meant free food and free beer. Also got to see a free movie.

For some reason, I can never find anything to do on some days, and others there are just too many options. Que sera.
